section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Margery Cuyler, illustrated by Will Hillenbrand
section-block.rac_book_summary: Animal friends gather in the playground, but they have some problems! Not to worry! Penguin coaches them on the right way to play. Ready to play safely?

section-block.rac_top-left_header: HEALTHY ME | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Nn, Rr, Xx Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: Review that letters have special sounds. Practice the beginning sounds in no, ride, and end sound in fix.
Invite children to sing “Row, Row, Row Your Boat,” using these words: “Swing, swing, swing on swings/Take our turn and smile/Merrily. This is how we play.” Repeat with slide.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Please Play Safe! written by Margery Cuyler and illustrated by Will Hillenbrand.
Pablo loves reading narratives about being safe, especially when the book is about play time! He wants to find out how Penguin will help keep his friends safe.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What does Penguin want his friends to do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The friends look excited about going to the playground. What happens on this page?
What happened to Pig when Elephant jumped off the wrong way? What should Elephant do when he gets off the seesaw?
I see Bear climbing up the slide! What would you climb before you slide?
Look at Rhino. What is he doing? Who can point to the letter R in Rhino? Let’s make the /r/ sound!
Now it’s time to leave the playground. What should the friends do before they go?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Penguin want his friends to play at the playground?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Penguin wants his friends to get off the slide carefully.
Penguin wants his friends to take turns.
Penguin wants his friends to take their playthings home.

section.rac_body-text: Write a short sentence about how to stay safe on the playground. Show children how you add a period at the end of the sentence.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Should friends take turns on the slide?
Friends should take t _____ (turns) on the slide.
Friends should take turns on the slide.
What are other ways friends can be safe on the slide?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: It is important to guide children to understand that sounds are represented by letters of the alphabet and that the letters represent sounds. This helps children learn to read words and break words into their sound parts.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Healthy Me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Move Carefully Through Surroundings
section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that it’s important to move carefully so they don’t bump into people or things. Choose one group at a time to walk carefully from the circle around the room using quiet feet. Notice and compliment friends. Invite children to share what was easy or hard to about getting around without touching.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder as we revisit the book Please Play Safe! by Margery Cuyler and illustrated by Will Hillenbrand.

Clifford knows he needs to move carefully when he moves around. He likes reading about how other animals move safely at the playground. Clifford says, “It’s important to stay safe on the Internet, too. Always ask a grown-up for help.”

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts. Use the Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Penguin wants his friends to walk instead of run. Why is that the right way for friends to go to the playground?
Chimpanzee is trying to cross the bars while her friend is still crossing. How does Lion feel? What’s a better thing for Chimpanzee to do? (MB)
I see Bear climbing up the slide! That’s not safe! Who will she end up bumping into? What do you climb before you slide? (MB)
Look at Hippo. How does she first throw the ball? Is that safe? Act out how Hippo can be safer. (MB)
What is Parrot doing? How should Parrot move her wings? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Tell children that, when we play near others, we need to be careful not to bump into anyone. We also need to show good manners. Play this game, called “Please and Thank You,” after reminding children to give their neighbor some space. Use a stuffed animal such as a duck. Invite one child to ask you for the duck by saying “Please, may I have the duck?” Give the child the duck and wait for him to say “Thank you” Continue with other pairs of children.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about a safe way to play with friends. Use end marks.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children in preschool are learning how to play and interact with their peers. It is a time when they begin to understand how their behavior, positive or negative, affects others. It’s an important time to teach children about sharing and taking turns on the playground. (Anthony, n.d.)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: HEALTHY ME | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that taking turns is one way to help them stay safe. Ask what happy things they can think about as they wait for their turns.

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Imagine you want to play a game on the computer. What would you say and do? After you finished the game, what would you do?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Please Play Safe! by Margery Cuyler and illustrated by Will Hillenbrand.
Pablo really likes reading Please Play Safe! because he likes the animal friends, and it reminds him of his own experiences at the playground.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
Why does Penguin want his friends to follow the rules?

section.rac_body-text: Reread the book and then read the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at how Penguin gets his friends to walk in a line! Who does Penguin remind you of in real life? (MB)
Elephant got off the see-saw without telling Pig! Has that ever happened to you? What did you do next?
Show me the slide in the picture. Now show me who will slide down it. Explain that the word slide sometimes means something you ride on and sometimes it means something you do.
Who likes to ride on scooters? Do you use a helmet? I see that Pig threw off his helmet! Why does Penguin want Pig to wear his helmet?
These friends are playing in the sandbox. Show me the right way to play in the sandbox.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
Why does Penguin want his friends to follow the rules?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for children to Turn and Talk.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He wants his friends to be safe.
He does not want his friends to get hurt.
He wants his friends to play nicely.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to draw and write about how to play safely. Ask children to use an end mark.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Penguin want his friends to be safe?
Penguin wants his friends to be s_____ (safe).
Penguin wants his friends to be safe.
Why is Penguin a good friend?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Making Connections to Real World
section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children have a purpose for reading, they can better understand the text. By showing children how the characters in a story are similar to people they encounter every day, they can assimilate the lesson from the story.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children all they have learned about playground safety this week. Why is it important to take turns? Why are rules important at the playground?
Share with children they will be be enjoying a rhyme about little animals. Show five stuffed animals. Have children take them away one by one and count the number left.
Introduce two new words, from the Big Chart of Big Ideas.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Big Chart of Big Ideas 5.2.4.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed. It is a nursery rhyme with a lesson.
Pablo loves rhyming words, so he’s very excited to read this nursery rhyme!
Please Play Safe! and Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed both focus on keeping our bodies safe. Let’s see what connections we can find between the two!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Safe and Sound
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text of the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many little froggies are on the bed? What are they doing? Should the froggies be jumping on the bed? Why not?
I see the letter j in a lot of words on this poster. What sound does the letter j make?
What happened to the froggies? Count how many froggies are on the bed. Did the froggies listen to the doctor?
After all the froggies got hurt they learned their lesson! What was their lesson?
What do you think Penguin would have said if he saw the froggies jumping on the bed?

section.rac_body-text: Have children sit in a circle. Put five stuffed froggies (or any animal) in the middle. Play a recording of the song. Invite a child to remove one froggie. Continue until are gone.
Provide a writing prompt about why it is important to play safely.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Counting nursery rhymes like Five Little Froggies Jumping On the Bed are both fun and important learning tools for young children. The rhythm and rhymes help children develop the ability to hear syllables and recognize the sounds phonemes make. Those skills lead them to being able to understand sound and letter relationships and blend sounds!

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to identify their favorite playground equipment and show how they use it. Encourage them to say how they use it safely and point out hazards that exist.
Review the Big Chart. Choose children to play the roles of mama, the doctor, and the froggies and act out the rhyme. Remind children to play safely.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Please Play Safe!
This book is about playing safely. The characters teach us lessons. Pablo loves to learn about safety! Pablo is also excited for today’s writing!
This week we read all about the how to play safely. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this question:
How can you stay safe at the playground?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend we are walking to the playground. Show me how keep your hands at your sides and get ready to walk in a line. Great!
Let’s pretend we’re at the climbing bars. I will choose one child. The rest of you can show me how you wait for your turn.
Let’s ride our scooters. But first, let’s put on our helmets.
Let’s pretend we have a rope. Let’s not have an accident. Let’s move our arms to turn the rope and jump safely! (MB)
Let’s pretend we are leaving the playground. Let’s pick up our toys and carry them home.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Invite children to Turn and Talk about the guiding question:
How can you stay safe at the playground?
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I can wait for my turn.
I will wear a helmet when I ride a scooter.
I will make sure I don’t bump into anyone.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write details about safe ways to play they practice while on the playground.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you wait for your turn?
I can wait for my t____ (turn).
I can wait for my turn.
What are other safety rules to use on the playground?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children need a variety of experiences and opportunities to learn language. Pair children with speakers who have strong English language skills. Pair children during outdoor playtime, and encourage partners to talk by providing simple phrases, such as, “Do you want to _______?” (swing, slide, throw the ball, play tag)
